Title: Entorhinal cortex of the monkey: V. Projections to the dentate gyrus, hippocampus, and subicular complex
Abstract: The topographic and laminar organization of entorhinal projections to the dentate gyrus, hippocampus, and subicular complex was investigated in the Macaca fascicularis monkey. Injections of 3H-amino acids were placed at various positions within the entorhinal cortex and the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers and terminals within the other fields of the hippocampal formation was determined. Injections of the retrograde tracers Fast blue, Diamidino yellow, and wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) were also placed into the dentate gyrus, hippocampus, and subicular complex, and the distribution of retrogradely labeled cells in the entorhinal cortex was plotted using a computer-aided digitizing system. The entorhinal cortex gave rise to projections that terminated in the subiculum, in the CA1, CA2, and CA3 fields of the hippocampus, and in the dentate gyrus. Projections to the dentate gyrus, and fields CA3 and CA2 of the hippocampus, originated preferentially in layers II and VI of the entorhinal cortex whereas projections to CA1 and to the subiculum originated mainly in layers III and V. Anterograde tracing experiments demonstrated that all regions of the entorhinal cortex project to the outer two-thirds of the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus and to much of the radial extent of the stratum lacunosum-moleculare of CA3 and CA2. While the terminal distributions of entorhinal projections to the dentate gyrus, CA3, and CA2 were not as clearly laminated as in the rat, projections from rostral levels of the entorhinal cortex preferentially innervated the outer portion of the molecular layer and stratum lacunosum-moleculare, whereas more caudal levels of the entorhinal cortex projected relatively more heavily to the deeper portions of the entorhinal terminal zones. The entorhinal projection to the CA1 field of the hippocampus and to the subiculum followed a transverse rather than radial gradient of distribution. Rostral levels of the entorhinal cortex terminated most heavily at the border of CA1 and the subiculum. More caudal levels of the entorhinal cortex projected to progressively more distal portions of the subiculum (towards the presubiculum) and more proximal portions of CA1 (towards CA2). Lateral portions of the entorhinal cortex projected to caudal levels of the recipient fields and more medial parts of the entorhinal cortex projected to progressively more rostral portions of the fields.

@InterMapRelations.Comments:
Witter and Amaral (1991) don't state from which parcellation scheme the description of the hippocampal formation and subicular complex has been adopted .
Nevertheless, it is quite possible that it  corresponds to the parcellation scheme used by Demeter et al. (J. Comp. Neurol.,1985), because in an another paper of Witter and Amaral (Witter et al. 1989, J. Neuroscience)  with a similat theme it has been clearly stated that they have adopted their parcellation scheme for the hippocampal formation from Demeter et al. (1985, J. Comp. Neurol.): "As it becomes clear that the entorhinal projection to the dentate gyrus is topographically organized in relation to the rostrocaudal or longitudinal extent of the dentate gyrus, it became necessary to adopt a nomenclature that would allow reference to be made to different positions along this axis. The termininology of Demeter et al. (1985) was appropriate for this purpose. In this nomenclature, the dentate gyrus and hippocampus can be characterized as having 3 major regions: the uncal portion, the genu and the body (Fig. 1B). " (Witter et al. 1989, J. Neuroscience, p. 218)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "In the term hippocampal formation we include the dentate gyrus, the hippocampus (which can be further divided into CA3, CA2, and CA1 fields), the subicular complex (that can be also divided into subiculum, presubiculum, and parasubiculum), and the entorhinal cortex." (p. 437)

"In the term hippocampal formation we include the dentate gyrus, the hippocampus (which can be further divided into CA3, CA2, and CA1 fields), the subicular complex (that can be also divided into subiculum, presubiculum, and parasubiculum), and the entorhinal cortex." (p. 437)

"In the term hippocampal formation we include the dentate gyrus, the hippocampus (which can be further divided into CA3, CA2, and CA1 fields), the subicular complex (that can be also divided into subiculum, presubiculum, and parasubiculum), and the entorhinal cortex." (p. 437)

"In the term hippocampal formation we include the dentate gyrus, the hippocampus (which can be further divided into CA3, CA2, and CA1 fields), the subicular complex (that can be also divided into subiculum, presubiculum, and parasubiculum), and the entorhinal cortex." (p. 437)

"In the term hippocampal formation we include the dentate gyrus, the hippocampus (which can be further divided into CA3, CA2, and CA1 fields), the subicular complex (that can be also divided into subiculum, presubiculum, and parasubiculum), and the entorhinal cortex." (p. 437)

"In the term hippocampal formation we include the dentate gyrus, the hippocampus (which can be further divided into CA3, CA2, and CA1 fields), the subicular complex (that can be also divided into subiculum, presubiculum, and parasubiculum), and the entorhinal cortex." (p. 437)

(p. 437)

@Methods.Comments: Thirteen animals were used for retrograde tracer experiments with DY, FB HRP, and WGA-HRP: "Retrogradely transported tracers were injected into the dentate gyrus, hippocampus, and subicular complex of 13 M. fascicularis monkeys. In five experimental animals, injections were placed bilaterally and two fluorescent tracers (Fats blue and Diamidino yellow) were injected at different rostrocaudal levels on each side. In three additional monkeys, two or three separate injections of retrograde tarcers [the fluorescent dyes and wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP)] were placed ipsilaterallly at different levels of the hippocampal formation. In the remaining experiments, animals received single injections of either HRP, WGA-HRP, or one of the fluorescent tracers. In total, these experiments yielded 33 injection sites of which 20 proved useful for these studies." (p. 438)

Thirteen animals were used for retrograde tracer experiments with DY, FB HRP, and WGA-HRP: "Retrogradely transported tracers were injected into the dentate gyrus, hippocampus, and subicular complex of 13 M. fascicularis monkeys. In five experimental animals, injections were placed bilaterally and two fluorescent tracers (Fats blue and Diamidino yellow) were injected at different rostrocaudal levels on each side. In three additional monkeys, two or three separate injections of retrograde tarcers [the fluorescent dyes and wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP)] were placed ipsilaterallly at different levels of the hippocampal formation. In the remaining experiments, animals received single injections of either HRP, WGA-HRP, or one of the fluorescent tracers. In total, these experiments yielded 33 injection sites of which 20 proved useful for these studies." (p. 438)
As you can see, the text doesn't say which cases belong to the animals, which received bilateral injections. Because of that it is not possible for us to compare the results derived from animals with unilateral injections with the results derived from animals with bilateral injections.

@Injections.Citation:
"In other cases, however (such as experiment M-4-89 described next), in which the injection involved either the proximal portion of CA1 or the distal part of the subiculum, the rostrocaudal gradient of labeling in layer III was reverse, i.e. more labeled cells were observed caudally than rostrally." (p. 449)
"In case M-4-89 (Fig. 11), an injection of Fast blue was placed at a rostrocaudal level slightly rostral to that in case M-5-87R. The injection involved the suprapyramidal blade of the dentate gyrus and a restricted proximal portion fo CA1." (p. 453)
"Line drawings of representative coronal sections taken at different rostrocaudal levels through the entorhinal cortex illustrating the distribution of retrogradely labeled cells following an injection of Fast blue that involved the suprapyramidal blade of the dentate gyrus, CA3, and CA2 and the proximal part of CA1 at a level comparable to that of the experiment illustrated in Fig. 10 (case M-4-89, inset)." (p. 454, description of figure 11)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "...Taken together, these experiments consistently indicated that neurons in layers II and VI preferentially innervated the dentate gyrus and the CA2 and CA3 fields of the hippocampus whereas cells in layers III and V projected preferentially to CA1 and the subiculum. In the following account, we will describe the ipsilateral distribution of retrogradely labeled cells observed in the entorhinal cortex following five representative injections." (p. 449)

@Injections.Citation:
"In experiment M-5-87L (Fig. 8), an injection of Fast blue involved the rostral part of the body and the genu of the infrapyramidal blade of the dentate gyrus with minor involvement of stratum oriens of CA3." (p. 449)
"Line drawings of representative coronal sections taken at different rostrocaudal levels through the entorhinal cortex illustrating the distribution of retrogradely labeled cells (small dots) following an injection of Fat blue involving the infrapyramidal blade of the dentate gyrus at the level of the rostral body of the hippocampal formation (case M-5-87L)." (p. 450, description of figure 8))

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "...Taken together, these experiments consistently indicated that neurons in layers II and VI preferentially innervated the dentate gyrus and the CA2 and CA3 fields of the hippocampus whereas cells in layers III and V projected preferentially to CA1 and the subiculum. In the following account, we will describe the ipsilateral distribution of retrogradely labeled cells observed in the entorhinal cortex following five representative injections." (p. 449)

@Methods.Comments:
" In a second series of experiments, single injections of 3H-amino acids were placed into the entorhinal cortex of 12 M. fascicularis and 2 rhesus monkeys. ...One of the M. fascicularis monkeys received injections bilaterally into the entorhinal cortex." (p. 438)
As you can see, the text doesn't say which cases belong to the animals, which received bilateral injections. Because of that it is not possible for us to compare the results derived from animals with unilateral injections with the results derived from animals with bilateral injections.

@Injections.Citation:
"There were four injections (DM-23, DM-15, DM-32, and DM-13) that involved different mediolateral positions of the border region between Ei and Ec (Fig. 1).
...The laterally placed injections (DM-13 and DM-32) presented a pattern of labeling that represented a gradual change from the labeling observed in experiments  (such MPI) with injections centered in Ei.
...In the experiments with the medially placed injections at the Ei/Ec border (DM-15 and DM-23), the terminal patterns differed substantially from those observed for the more laterally placed injections in Ei and for the injections situated more rostrally in the entorhinal cortex." (p. 447)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation:
"The results of our anterograde tracing experiments can be summarized in the following way. All 3H-amino acid injections in the entorhinal cortex resulted in labeling of the outer two-thirds of the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus , the full radial width of stratum lacunosum-moleculare fo all subfields of the hippocampus, and the outer two-thirds to three-quarters of the molecular layer of the subiculum. In the dentate gyrus and CA3 and CA2 fields of the hippocampus, labeled fibers and terminals were observed throughout the full transverse extents of the terminal fields in each case but the density of termination along the radial axis differed depending on the injection site. In CA1 and the subiculum, in contrast, the terminal field always had a restricted transverse distribution but was more or less evenly labeled throughout the entire radial width of the entorhinal synaptic region. 
Following all injections, weak labeling was present in the molecular layer and layer II of the pre-and parasubiculum; the parasubiculum was slightly more densely labeled. As noted above, it was extremely difficult to determine whether this light labeling in the pre-and parasubiculum represented terminal labeling or was exclusively associated with fibers of passage. We shall not comment further on the distribution of label in these fields. In most experimental cases, the hilus of the dentate gyrus also appeared to have labeling that was slightly above background levels. We should note that injections that gave rise to labeled projections to caudal levels of the ipsilateral hippocampal formation also labeled commissural fibers that terninated in caudal levels of the contralateral hippocampal formation. The contralateral projection was very weak and mainly directed to the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus; additional, though very weak, labeling was also present in the hippocampus (Amaral et al., '84; Witter et al., '89b)." (p. 445)

@Injections.Citation:
"There were four injections (DM-23, DM-15, DM-32, and DM-13) that involved different mediolateral positions of the border region between Ei and Ec (Fig. 1).
...The laterally placed injections (DM-13 and DM-32) presented a pattern of labeling that represented a gradual change from the labeling observed in experiments  (such MPI) with injections centered in Ei.
...In the experiments with the medially placed injections at the Ei/Ec border (DM-15 and DM-23), the terminal patterns differed substantially from those observed for the more laterally placed injections in Ei and for the injections situated more rostrally in the entorhinal cortex." (p. 447)

In the dentate gyrus and CA3 and CA2 fields of the hippocampus, labeled fibers and terminals were observed throughout the full transverse extents of the terminal fields in each case but the density of termination along the radial axis differed depending on the injection site. The contralateral projection was very weak and mainly directed to the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus; additional, though very weak, labeling was also present in the hippocampus (Amaral et al., '84; Witter et al., '89b)." (p. 445)

@Injections.Citation: "There were two injections that were located quite caudally in the entorhinal cortex. One injection (in experiment MPV) was centered in Ec, and the most caudal injection (in experiment DM-17) involved the caudomedial part of Ecl and the adjacent parasubiculum." (p. 447)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation:
"The results of our anterograde tracing experiments can be summarized in the following way. All 3H-amino acid injections in the entorhinal cortex resulted in labeling of the outer two-thirds of the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus , the full radial width of stratum lacunosum-moleculare fo all subfields of the hippocampus, and the outer two-thirds to three-quarters of the molecular layer of the subiculum. In the dentate gyrus and CA3 and CA2 fields of the hippocampus, labeled fibers and terminals were observed throughout the full transverse extents of the terminal fields in each case but the density of termination along the radial axis differed depending on the injection site. In CA1 and the subiculum, in contrast, the terminal field always had a restricted transverse distribution but was more or less evenly labeled throughout the entire radial width of the entorhinal synaptic region. 
Following all injections, weak labeling was present in the molecular layer and layer II of the pre-and parasubiculum; the parasubiculum was slightly more densely labeled. As noted above, it was extremely difficult to determine whether this light labeling in the pre-and parasubiculum represented terminal labeling or was exclusively associated with fibers of passage. We shall not comment further on the distribution of label in these fields. In most experimental cases, the hilus of the dentate gyrus also appeared to have labeling that was slightly above background levels. We should note that injections that gave rise to labeled projections to caudal levels of the ipsilateral hippocampal formation also labeled commissural fibers that terninated in caudal levels of the contralateral hippocampal formation. The contralateral projection was very weak and mainly directed to the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus; additional, though very weak, labeling was also present in the hippocampus (Amaral et al., '84; Witter et al., '89b)." (p. 445)

@Injections.Citation:
"There were four injections (DM-23, DM-15, DM-32, and DM-13) that involved different mediolateral positions of the border region between Ei and Ec (Fig. 1).
...The laterally placed injections (DM-13 and DM-32) presented a pattern of labeling that represented a gradual change from the labeling observed in experiments  (such MPI) with injections centered in Ei.
...In the experiments with the medially placed injections at the Ei/Ec border (DM-15 and DM-23), the terminal patterns differed substantially from those observed for the more laterally placed injections in Ei and for the injections situated more rostrally in the entorhinal cortex." (p. 447)

Following all injections, weak labeling was present in the molecular layer and layer II of the pre-and parasubiculum; the parasubiculum was slightly more densely labeled. As noted above, it was extremely difficult to determine whether this light labeling in the pre-and parasubiculum represented terminal labeling or was exclusively associated with fibers of passage. We shall not comment further on the distribution of label in these fields. In most experimental cases, the hilus of the dentate gyrus also appeared to have labeling that was slightly above background levels. We should note that injections that gave rise to labeled projections to caudal levels of the ipsilateral hippocampal formation also labeled commissural fibers that terninated in caudal levels of the contralateral hippocampal formation. The contralateral projection was very weak and mainly directed to the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus; additional, though very weak, labeling was also present in the hippocampus (Amaral et al., '84; Witter et al., '89b)." (p. 445)

@Injections.Citation:
"Three of the 3H-amino acid injections (DM-25, MPI, and DM-34) mainly involved the intermediate division of the entorhinal cortex (Ei). One of these injections (MPI), located in a mid transverse position within Ei resulted in a rostrocaudal distribution of labeling similar to that in experiment DM-38 (Fig. 3).
...There were two additional  experiments with injections that mainly involved Ei (Fig. 1). In experiment DM-34, where the injection was laterally placed and had minor involvement of El, anterogradely transported label was densest in the caudal one-third of the body of the hippocampal formation. In the more medially placed injection (DM-25, which had minor involvement of Er) labeling was densest in the uncal portion and genu of the hippocampus." (p. 447)

"In experiment M-10-87, the injection was located at approximately the same rostrocaudal level as the one in DM-38 (Fig. 1) but involved mainly the lateral part of the entorhinal cortex (ELr). As illustrated photographically in Fig. 5A, this injection resulted in labeling of the same hippocampal fields labeled in DM-38. As would be expected from the lateral position of this injection site, the heaviest labeling was observed at a level caudal to that observed in experiment DM-38. However, the distribution of labeling in the dentate gyrus, CA3, and CA2 exhibited a radial pattern comparable to that observed in DM-38 and the transverse location of labeling in CA1 and the subiculum was also similar in the two cases." (pp. 445, 447)

@Methods_Animals.Comments: All of the cynomolgus monkeys were male, whereas the rhesus monkeys were of either sex.

@Methods.Comments:
Thirteen animals were used for retrograde tracer experiments with DY, FB HRP, and WGA-HRP: "Retrogradely transported tracers were injected into the dentate gyrus, hippocampus, and subicular complex of 13 M. fascicularis monkeys. In five experimental animals, injections were placed bilaterally and two fluorescent tracers (Fats blue and Diamidino yellow) were injected at different rostrocaudal levels on each side. In three additional monkeys, two or three separate injections of retrograde tarcers [the fluorescent dyes and wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP)] were placed ipsilaterallly at different levels of the hippocampal formation. In the remaining experiments, animals received single injections of either HRP, WGA-HRP, or one of the fluorescent tracers. In total, these experiments yielded 33 injection sites of which 20 proved useful for these studies." (p. 438)
As you can see, the text doesn't say which cases belong to the animals, which received bilateral injections. Because of that it is not possible for us to compare the results derived from animals with unilateral injections with the results derived from animals with bilateral injections.

@Injections.Citation:
"In experiment M-3-87R (Fig. 9), the injection of Diamidino yellow was located at a midportion of the body of the hippocampus and was centered in the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus and stratum lacunosum-moleculare of fields CA3 and CA2 of the hippocampus." (p. 449)
"Line drawings of representative coronal sections taken at different rostrocaudal levels through the entorhinal cortex illustrating the distribution of retrogradely labeled cells following a caudally placed injection of Diamidino yellow involving the dentate gyrus and fields CA3 and CA2 of the hippocampus (case M-3-87R, inset)." (p. 451, description of figure 9)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "...Taken together, these experiments consistently indicated that neurons in layers II and VI preferentially innervated the dentate gyrus and the CA2 and CA3 fields of the hippocampus whereas cells in layers III and V projected preferentially to CA1 and the subiculum. In the following account, we will describe the ipsilateral distribution of retrogradely labeled cells observed in the entorhinal cortex following five representative injections." (p. 449)

@Injections.Citation:
"In the last retrograde case to be described (M-5-87L), an injection of Diamidino yellow was placed somewhat caudally to the injections in the previous two cases. The injection involved the infrapyramidal blade of the denate gyrus and the distal portion of the subiculum." (p. 453)
"Line drawings of representative coronal sections taken at different rostrocaudal levels through the entorhinal cortex illustrating the distribution of retrogradely cells following a caudal injection of Diamidino yellow involving the infrapyramidal blade of the dentate gyrus and the distal part of the subiculum (case M-5-87L, inset)." (p. 455, description of figure 12)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "...Taken together, these experiments consistently indicated that neurons in layers II and VI preferentially innervated the dentate gyrus and the CA2 and CA3 fields of the hippocampus whereas cells in layers III and V projected preferentially to CA1 and the subiculum. In the following account, we will describe the ipsilateral distribution of retrogradely labeled cells observed in the entorhinal cortex following five representative injections." (p. 449)

@Injections.Citation:
"In experiment M-5-87R (Fig. 10), an injection of Diamidino yellow was placed caudally in the hippocampal formation, involving the border zone between field CA1 and the subiculum. 
...As noted above, the injection in M-5-87R involved the border zone between CA1 and the subiculum." (p. 449)
"The injection of Diamidino yellow involved the distal portion of CA1 and the adjacent proximal portion of the subiculum." (p. 452, description of figure 10)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "...Taken together, these experiments consistently indicated that neurons in layers II and VI preferentially innervated the dentate gyrus and the CA2 and CA3 fields of the hippocampus whereas cells in layers III and V projected preferentially to CA1 and the subiculum. In the following account, we will describe the ipsilateral distribution of retrogradely labeled cells observed in the entorhinal cortex following five representative injections." (p. 449)

publication.title: Entorhinal cortex of the monkey: V. Projections to the dentate gyrus, hippocampus, and subicular complex
publication.abstract: The topographic and laminar organization of entorhinal projections to the dentate gyrus, hippocampus, and subicular complex was investigated in the Macaca fascicularis monkey. Injections of 3H-amino acids were placed at various positions within the entorhinal cortex and the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers and terminals within the other fields of the hippocampal formation was determined. Injections of the retrograde tracers Fast blue, Diamidino yellow, and wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) were also placed into the dentate gyrus, hippocampus, and subicular complex, and the distribution of retrogradely labeled cells in the entorhinal cortex was plotted using a computer-aided digitizing system. The entorhinal cortex gave rise to projections that terminated in the subiculum, in the CA1, CA2, and CA3 fields of the hippocampus, and in the dentate gyrus. Projections to the dentate gyrus, and fields CA3 and CA2 of the hippocampus, originated preferentially in layers II and VI of the entorhinal cortex whereas projections to CA1 and to the subiculum originated mainly in layers III and V. Anterograde tracing experiments demonstrated that all regions of the entorhinal cortex project to the outer two-thirds of the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus and to much of the radial extent of the stratum lacunosum-moleculare of CA3 and CA2. While the terminal distributions of entorhinal projections to the dentate gyrus, CA3, and CA2 were not as clearly laminated as in the rat, projections from rostral levels of the entorhinal cortex preferentially innervated the outer portion of the molecular layer and stratum lacunosum-moleculare, whereas more caudal levels of the entorhinal cortex projected relatively more heavily to the deeper portions of the entorhinal terminal zones. The entorhinal projection to the CA1 field of the hippocampus and to the subiculum followed a transverse rather than radial gradient of distribution. Rostral levels of the entorhinal cortex terminated most heavily at the border of CA1 and the subiculum. More caudal levels of the entorhinal cortex projected to progressively more distal portions of the subiculum (towards the presubiculum) and more proximal portions of CA1 (towards CA2). Lateral portions of the entorhinal cortex projected to caudal levels of the recipient fields and more medial parts of the entorhinal cortex projected to progressively more rostral portions of the fields.
